tn.text: Here "me" refers to God.

This refers to the people who live on the islands and in the lands bordering or beyond the Mediterranean Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
Translate this phrase in the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:40:29|40:31]].

tn.ref: let them come near and speak; let us come near together to argue a dispute
tn.text: These two phrases share similar meanings. The second explains the reason for the first. AT: "then let them come near so they may speak and reason with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Who has stirred up one from the east, calling him in righteousness to his service?
tn.text: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he is the one who caused this ruler from the east to be victorious. AT: "I am the one who called this powerful ruler from the east and put him in my good service." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: He hands nations over to him
tn.text: "I give the nations over to him" or "The one who does these things hands nations over to him"

tn.ref: He turns them to dust with his sword, like windblown stubble with his bow
tn.text: The nations whom the one from the east will conquer are compared to dust and stubble, both because they will become very small like those things and because his army will scatter them easily. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Yahweh continues speaking to the coastlands and the nations.

tn.ref: He pursues them and passes by safely
tn.text: "The ruler from the east pursues the nations"

tn.ref: by a swift path that his feet scarcely touch
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) this is a metaphor in which he and his army moving very quickly is spoken of as if his feet barely touch the ground. AT: "by a path on which he moves with great speed" or 2) "feet" is a synecdoche and the phrase indicates that this is a path that they have not traveled before. AT: "by a path that he has never traveled before" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Who has performed and accomplished these deeds?
tn.text: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he is the one who has done these things. AT: "I have performed and accomplished these deeds." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Who has summoned the generations from the beginning?
tn.text: Here the word "generations" represents all of human history, which Yahweh created and directed throughout history. The rhetorical question anticipates the answer, Yahweh. AT: "I have summoned the generations of humanity from the beginning." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh is the one who has done these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: the first, and with the last ones
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) that Yahweh existed before creation and will exist at the end of creation or 2) that Yahweh was before the first generation of humanity and will be at the last generation of humanity.
Yahweh continues speaking.

tn.ref: The isles ... the ends of the earth
tn.text: These phrases represent the people who live in those places. AT: "People who live on the isles ... people who live at the ends of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
You can translate "isles" the same way you translated "coastlands" in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:41:01|41:1]].
The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. AT "the farthest places of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This doublet means that the people gather together. AT: "they come together" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
an iron block on which a person shapes metal with a hammer
Here the word "welding" refers to the process of fastening the gold to the wood as the workers finish making the idol.

tn.ref: They fasten it with nails so it will not topple over.
tn.text: Here "it" refers to the idol that they have made.
Yahweh continues speaking.

tn.ref: you whom I am bringing back from the ends of the earth, and whom I called from the far away places
tn.text: These two lines mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh is bringing the people of Israel back to their land from distant countries. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. Translate this in the same way you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:41:05|41:5]]. AT "the farthest places of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I have chosen you and not rejected you
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second states in negative terms what the first states in positive terms. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: I will uphold you with my righteous right hand
tn.text: Yahweh strengthening his people is spoken of as if he were holding them with his hand. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "right hand" represents Yahweh's power. Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh's right hand is righteous in that he will always do the right thing. AT: "my righteous power" or 2) Yahweh's right hand is victorious in that he will always succeed in what he does. AT: "my victorious power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: they will be ashamed and disgraced, all who have been angry with you
tn.text: "all who have been angry with you will be ashamed and disgraced"
These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of their shame. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: they will be as nothing and will perish, those who oppose you
tn.text: "those who oppose you will be as nothing and will perish"
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: I ... will hold your right hand
tn.text: Yahweh helping the people of Israel is spoken of as if he were holding their right hand. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: Jacob you worm, and you men of Israel
tn.text: Here "Jacob" and "men of Israel" mean the same thing. AT: "you people of Israel who are like worms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

Possible meanings are 1) that this refers to the opinions of other nations regarding the people of Israel or 2) that this refers to Israel's own opinion of themselves. Yahweh speaks of their insignificance as if they were a worm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "declaration" is expressed as the verb "declared" or "solemnly said." AT: "Yahweh declared" or "Yahweh solemnly said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Translate this phrase in the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:01:04|1:4]].

tn.ref: I am making you like a sharp threshing sledge ... you will make the hills like chaff
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of enabling Israel to defeat their enemies as if he were making the nation a threshing sledge that will level mountains. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
A threshing sledge was a board with sharp spikes that someone would drag over the wheat to separate the grain from the chaff.
edged** - This refers to the edges of the spikes that were attached to the threshing sledge. That they are "two-edged" means that they are very sharp.

tn.ref: you will thresh the mountains and crush them
tn.text: Instead of threshing grain, Israel will thresh mountains, which represent the powerful nations that were Israel's enemies. AT: "you will thresh your enemies and crush them as if they were grain, even though they appear to be as strong as mountains" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: you will make the hills like chaff
tn.text: This line has a meaning similar to the previous line but represents the next step in the process of threshing grain. The hills, which represent Israel's enemies, will be like worthless chaff. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues to use the metaphor of separating grain from chaff to describe how Israel will defeat their enemies.

tn.ref: You will winnow them ... the wind will scatter them
tn.text: Here the word "them" refers to the mountains and hill in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:41:14|41:15]]. This represents the next step in the process of threshing grain, in which the grain is winnowed to get rid of the chaff. Israel's enemies will disappear like chaff blown away by the wind. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the wind will carry them away; the wind will scatter them
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. AT: "the wind will blow them away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

Yahweh speaks of people who are in extreme need as if they are extremely thirsty, and of his provision for them as if he caused water to appear in places where it normally would not appear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues speaking.

tn.ref: the myrtle ... the pines and the cypress box trees
tn.text: These are types of trees. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: the hand of Yahweh has done this
tn.text: Here the word "hand" represents Yahweh himself. AT: "Yahweh has done this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

In these verses, Yahweh is mocking the people and their idols. He is challenging the idols to tell what will happen in the future, but he knows they cannot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
Yahweh continues to mock the idols and the people who worship them. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:41:21|41:21-22]])
The words "good" and "evil" form a merism and represent anything. AT: "do anything at all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
Here "you" is plural and refers to the idols. AT: "the person who chooses you idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_youdual]])
Yahweh continues speaking.
Yahweh speaks of appointing a person as if he raised that person up. AT: "I have appointed one" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the east, the direction from which the sun rises. AT: "from the east" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: him who calls on my name
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) that this person invokes Yahweh for his success or 2) that this person worships Yahweh.
Conquering the rulers of other nations is spoken of as if it were trampling them under foot. AT: "he will conquer the rulers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: like a potter who is treading on the clay
tn.text: Yahweh compares the way in which this person will trample the other rulers with the way that a potter tramples on clay to mix it with water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Who announced this from the beginning, that we might know? Before this time, that we may say, "He is right"?
tn.text: Yahweh uses these rhetorical questions to mock the idols that the people worship. The implied answers are 1) that the idols have not done these things and 2) that Yahweh is the one who has done these things. AT: "None of the idols announced this from the beginning, that we might know. And none of them announced this before time, that we may say, 'He is right.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and[[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: Indeed none of them decreed it, yes, none heard you say anything
tn.text: "Indeed, none of the idols decreed it. Indeed, no one heard you idols say anything"
Yahweh continues speaking.
"not one idol"

tn.ref: their cast metal figures are wind and emptiness
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of the worthlessness of the idols as if the idols are wind and nothing at all. AT: "their idols are all worthless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
